Package projects.graph

Class AdjacencyListGraph

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.graph.Graph
      • projects.graph.AdjacencyListGraph
  • public class AdjacencyListGraph
extends Graph

    AdjacencyListGraph is a Graph implemented as an adjacency list, i.e a one-dimensional array of linked lists, where A(i) is a linked list containing the neighbors of node i and the corresponding edges' weights. The neighbors of a given node are defined as the nodes it points to (if any).

    Other implementations besides linked lists are possible (e.g BSTs over the weight of the edge), yet for this project we will keep it simple and stick to that basic implementation. One of its advantages is that, because the lists do not need to be sorted in any way, the insertion of a new edge is a O(1) operation (find the list corresponding to the source node in O(1) and add the new list node up front.

    Author:
    --- YOUR NAME HERE! ---
    See Also:
    Graph, AdjacencyMatrixGraph, SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph

    • Method Detail

      • addNode

        public void addNode()
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Add a new node to the graph. The node will be characterized by its index of insertion, such that the first time this method is called, a node with index ' 0 ' is stored in the graph, the second one we will store a node with index ' 1 ', etc, etc.

        Specified by:
        addNode in class Graph

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge​(int source,
                    int dest,
                    int weight)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Adds an edge from node source to node dest in the graph, attaching to it weight equal to weight. In this implementation, we don't allow weights to be negative. If a weight that is either negative or greater than Graph.INFINITY is provided, the method should throw a RuntimeException. If the edge already exists, its weight should be updated to the parameter value.

        If either source or dest don't exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined. This means that you can do whatever you want, as long as you don't store extra edges or nodes in the graph. You can throw a RuntimeException, return null, print a message, anything. We do not test for this case.

        We treat the addition of a weight with zero weight exactly the same way we would treat the deletion of an edge through Graph.deleteEdge(int, int). So, the calls add(i, j, 0) and deleteEdge(i, j) are equivalent.

        Specified by:
        addEdge in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The "sink" node of the edge.
        weight - The weight of the edge.

      • deleteEdge

        public void deleteEdge​(int source,
                       int dest)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Delete the edge from source to dest. If the edge does not exist, or if either node does not exist in the graph, no action should be performed.

        We would like to particularly stress that removing an edge does not in any way imply removing its constituent nodes, even if the nodes end up being singleton disconnected components!

        Specified by:
        deleteEdge in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The "source" node of the edge.
        dest - The "sink" node of the edge.

      • edgeBetween

        public boolean edgeBetween​(int source,
                           int dest)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Queries the graph about the existence of an edge from source to dest. If either source or dest are not contained by the graph, then the edge itself cannot possibly exist and the method should return false.

        Specified by:
        edgeBetween in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, source, dest and the edge source->dest all exist in the graph, false otherwise.

      • getEdgeWeight

        public int getEdgeWeight​(int source,
                         int dest)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Returns the weight of the edge source->dest. If the edge does not exist (either because at least one of the two nodes does not exist or because they both exist but there is no edge between them), this method should return 0.

        Specified by:
        getEdgeWeight in class Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        dest - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        the weight of the edge source->dest

      • getNeighbors

        public java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> getNeighbors​(int node)
        Description copied from class: Graph

        Retrieves the "neighbor" nodes of the provided node, i.e all the nodes to which it is connected (whether it is the source OR sink). If the node does not exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined; you can do whatever you want (and that helps you debug!) and we don't test for it. If the node does exist in the graph but it has no neighbors, the returned Set should be non-null, but empty (size 0).

        Specified by:
        getNeighbors in class Graph
        Parameters:
        node - The node to retrieve the neighbors of.
        Returns:
        A Set of all nodes to which node is incident (whether it is the source OR sink).

      • toAdjacencyMatrixGraph

        public AdjacencyMatrixGraph toAdjacencyMatrixGraph()
        Transforms this into an instance of AdjacencyMatrixGraph. This is an O(E) operation. You are not allowed to implement this method by using other transformation methods. For example, you cannot implement it with the line of code toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph().toAdjacencyMatrixGraph().
        Returns:
        An instance of AdjacencyMatrixGraph.

      • toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph

        public SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph()
        Transforms this into an instance of AdjacencyMatrixGraph. This is an O(E) operation. You are not allowed to implement this method by using other transformation methods. For example, you cannot implement it with the line of code toAdjacencyMatrixGraph().toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph().
        Returns:
        An instance of AdjacencyMatrixGraph.
